Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Refining Analysis Methods for Examining Human Gut Bacteria
Award.AbstractNarration:
The human gut microbiome is the community of microbes living in the intestinal tract, including the stomach, the small and large intestines, and the colon. The composition of the gut microbiome affects many aspects of human health, including the incidence of inflammatory diseases of the bowel (e.g. inflammatory bowel disease) and other parts of the body (e.g. rheumatoid arthritis), various cancers, and diabetes. Many researchers use a mouse model in their investigations of the gut microbiome. However, the mouse model, while convenient for research, is not necessarily a reliable model as a predictor of human response to the microbiome. Therefore, it is imperative to be trained in research on the human microbiome itself. This is possible in the laboratory of Professor Gerald Tannock, at the University of Otago, Dunedin, New Zealand. The purpose of this research is to gain valuable expertise in human microbiome research by refining the methodology used by Professor Tannock to analyze the structure of infant gut microbial communities.

Studies involving the microbiome often require the use of next-generation, high-throughput sequencing (HTS). Despite the ubiquitous use of sequencing, there is no approved universal method for analyzing this data, as research-directed questions will often call for different bioinformatic approaches. This can cause problems when attempting to compare the results from two studies that used two different methods for analyzing the data. This project will incorporate the latest analytical tools to search for fine detail trends in microbiome data that may be hidden when using default approaches. QIIME is a commonly used software package that focuses on quality screening and analysis of HTS data from amplified marker genes. We will utilize this package to test different approaches of analyzing sequencing data, and will compare outputs in an attempt to reveal previously hidden associations between individual microbiomes. This study will allow us to suggest improved analysis pipelines that may be implemented by other investigators working in the field of gut microbiome research.

This award under the East Asia and Pacific Summer Institutes program supports summer research by a U.S. graduate student and is jointly funded by NSF and the Royal Society of New Zealand.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The human gut microbiome is the community of microbes living in the intestinal tract, including the stomach, the small and large intestines, and the colon. The composition of the gut microbiome affects many aspects of human health, including the incidence of inflammatory diseases of the bowel (e.g. inflammatory bowel disease) and other parts of the body (e.g. rheumatoid arthritis), various cancers, and diabetes. Researchers are attempting to learn the mechanisms by which the structure of the microbiome influences health using both mouse models and human patients. To determine what microbial communities are present in the area of interest, DNA must be extracted from samples, sequenced, and analysed. There are multiple methods used by researchers to analyse these data. One objective of this study was to compare the differences between analysis methods, and to observe if these differences result in different biological conclusions. A secondary objective of this study was to provide me with training in QIIME (the analysis program), which is necessary to complete my master’s thesis research. This experience also provided me with an opportunity to work with the human microbiome, as opposed to the mouse microbiome which is the focus of my thesis.

 

To compare the various analysis methods, data from infant stools were used. DNA was extracted from the stools and a library, or pooled DNA sequences from all samples, was created. QIIME, a ubiquitous sequencing analysis platform, was used to analyse the library. Within QIIME there are many different options when analysing sequences. The first option tested was clustering technique, or the method of assigning individual DNA sequences into distinct groups of similar sequences. There are three types of clustering: closed reference, de novo, and open reference. Closed reference clustering compares and clusters each sequence to a reference database of known DNA sequences. De novo clustering compares each sequence to all other sequences within the library without the use of a reference database. Open reference clustering uses a de novo approach, then uses a closed reference approach to cluster any sequences that failed to cluster in the de novo approach. No difference was found between the clustering methods.

 

Following clustering, each cluster is assigned a taxonomy. In this study two taxonomic databases were tested: Silva123 and Greengenes. Greengenes is not a curated database and is the default database used in QIIME, while Silva123 is curated. Clusters generated from the library are assigned taxonomy based on the similarity to an operational taxonomic unit in the taxonomic database. In addition, two clustering algorithms were tested: BLAST and UCLUST. No difference was found between taxonomic assignment methods.

 

Overall I found no differences between methods of analysis tested. A common difficulty in comparing studies is the differences in analysis methods. If different methods yield different results, then two studies using two different methods are not comparable. Because these different methods yield a similar biological conclusion, comparing studies using these different methods is not out of the question.

 

Because the analysis of methods was completed before the end of the program, I was able to complete an additional small project: an analysis of the differences in the gut microbiomes of infants. The host lab has access to infant microbiome data from three different countries: New Zealand, Indonesia, and Singapore. Factors that were analysed included: gender, country, age, and the interaction between gender and age. Microbiomes were significantly different between all three countries, between both genders, and between ages. There was also a significant interaction between age and gender. This means that a female’s microbiome matures differently than a male’s microbiome.

 

This project has allowed me to become an expert in QIIME analysis which is an essential part of my thesis work. Prior to this experience I had no exposure to high throughput sequencing analysis. Through this project I was able to gain valuable training in QIIME, and was able to learn about the underlying framework and theory that allows QIIME to work. This deep understanding of the analysis pipeline is an essential component of being able to effectively use it. This experience was also my first exposure to working with the human microbiome, which was a very interesting aspect of this experience. The experience and training I gained through this program will be used for the remainder of my research career.
